awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Functional and genomic diversity in vitamin B1 metabolism and impacts on plankton networks and productivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Many organisms, from humans to microbes, need to acquire vitamins by ingesting them as food or taking them up directly from the environment.  Vitamins are important to individual organisms, but they also have the potential to alter the health and productivity of entire ecosystems.  This project will explore the production and consumption of vitamin B1 (thiamin) by planktonic cells that are the base of the ocean food chain. It will also examine the way that different microorganisms may interact harmoniously and/or competitively in metabolizing thiamin and similar molecules.  A network analysis of data will help determine the role that these substances play in controlling microbial biodiversity and photosynthesis in sea water, and the response of microorganisms to changing ocean conditions.  This project will also train postdoctoral scholars, graduate students and underdergraduates, and will support a teacher professional development program that prepares low-income, historically underrepresented, and other educationally underserved students from rural areas to graduate from high school, enroll and succeed in higher education, and pursue STEM careers.  

Plankton evolved diverse strategies to acquire thiamin, including salvaging thiamin-related compounds from the environment.  This project will: 1) survey metabolic adaptions related to thiamin in plankton, using comparative genomics and evolution (high throughput DNA sequencing); 2) test important functional predictions using cultures and analytical chemistry (chemostats and mass spectrometry); 3) measure plankton interactions in natural and artificially stimulated phytoplankton blooms. This investigation will join the oceanographic cruises of two major field campaigns in the North Atlantic Ocean. The results will be integrated using several computational approaches to interpret variations in microbial community structure, the role of biochemical, genomic and taxonomic diversity in maintaining biodiversity patterns of today's oceans, as well as potential future oceans, and microbial networks. Specific aspects of thiamin metabolism pathways will be explored in the context of understanding microbial chemical interactions. These different levels of biodiversity and thiamin cycling will be investigated across transitions between productive phytoplankton blooms and the stratified, oligotrophic conditions that typify the warmer oceans predicted under several environmental change scenarios.

por.por_cntn:
Vitamin B1 is essential for all forms of life on earth ranging from humans to microbes. This vitamin is very important to life as it enables photosynthetic organisms like plants to fix carbon, and heterotrophic organisms like animals to break down carbon (food).  This is no different in the ocean where there are vast populations of microorganisms that are responsible for half of the planet’s carbon fixation and oxygen production. As a result, these microorganisms play a key role in modulating the impacts of anthropogenic climate change. Organisms must have sufficient vitamin B1 to complete these critical processes, yet recent research has indicated that most marine microbes cannot synthesize their own vitamin B1, and instead must acquire it from exogenous sources. A small subset of marine microbes are able to synthesize vitamin B1, and they are the source of vitamin B1 to the entire community. We hypothesize that vitamin B1 serves as a sort of “microbial currency” that is exchanged between producers and consumers, and that the nature of the “vitamin B1 economy” structures interactions between microbial groups. The nature of these vitamin B1-mediated microbial interactions could have profound impacts ranging from modulating climate change to the stability of higher trophic levels (fisheries). 

            We investigated vitamin B1’s impact on microbial interactions by combining analytical chemistry and microbiology methods both in laboratory experiments and oceanographic expeditions. We developed novel methods to measure vitamin B1, its biosynthetic precursors, and breakdown products using liquid chromatography mass spectrometry.  We then used these methods to measure the dissolved concentrations of vitamin B1 and its related compounds in marine environments ranging from the California Current to the Bermuda Atlantic Timeseries Study site in the Sargasso Sea. The concentrations we measured are within the picomolar range, which is likely too low to support the needs of the microbes present, suggesting this valuable compound is consumed by microbes as fast as it is produced. This finding was further supported by our observations that the B1 concentrations fluctuate on a day-night cycle, with peak concentrations occurring during the day, which indicates that changes in microbial activity change the availability of this compound.   We then used radioisotope labeled vitamin B1 compounds (HMP) and cell cultures of the most abundant marine bacteria (SAR11, which is unable to completely synthesize vitamin B1) to determine how quickly HMP could be consumed.  Our findings determined that SAR11 has a specific, high affinity transporter for HMP. These findings were confirmed when we conducted the same type of experiments at sea aboard the Research Vessel Atlantic Explorer in the Sargasso Sea, where we determined that rates of environmental vitamin B1 compound uptake match those measured in our laboratory, and that the rates we measured could explain the day-night changes we observed in vitamin B1 compound concentrations.  In total, our work has shown that vitamin B1 is exchanged by microbes, and that microbial activity controls the amount of vitamin B1 present in the system. Our data will allow for broader, more precise, modeling of the “vitamin B1 economy” and help us to understand its impact on global microbial populations and their role in biogeochemical cycles.  In a rapidly changing climate and ocean it is now more important than ever to gain a mechanistic understanding of the fine scale controls on how microbes function. 

            Throughout this project we communicated our findings to the broader scientific field and the public at-large.  This project supported the training of a postdoctoral researcher, a Master’s degree student and two undergraduate honors thesis students. Researchers participated in three oceanographic research cruises and presented results to the scientific community in two scientific publications and at six scientific meetings.  We worked closely with the Oregon State University Precollege Programs Office, using our research findings to develop comprehensive lesson plans for elementary, middle, and high school science classrooms. These lesson plans utilized a board game that we developed in our lab that models the way microbes interact in the ocean. They were presented to teachers at six professional development seminars and was successfully deployed in underserved schools in rural communities across the state of Oregon. We published our lesson plans and board game in the journal The Science Teacher, making it freely available to teachers across the country.
